content.description:
o·nus

(n.)

1.

A difficult or disagreeable responsibility or necessity; a burden or obligation.

2.

A stigma or blame.

and a burden it is....this route fits both definitions.

Difficult climbing up a

stigmatic

face. Begin up a right leaning series of blocks and climb this odd section to a mini roof and feasible rest. Clip a bolt and quickly meet a sparse, barren crux. The route quickly turns to some powerful movement through a tough sequence over some very thin terrain. Fire this crux, then hold on for the pocket to pocket finish.

Powerful and tweaky, don't let this become Your Onus!
content.location:
Your Onus

is just right of

The Bleaker

at the Main Wall.

content.description:
Nice steady climbing.

A good warmup, which this crag lacked.
content.location: This is the left route on a wall between the main wall and before you turn the corner for Long Shadows. Hidden behind a big tree.

content.description: A powerful series of pinches, gastons and sidepulls lead the way to a thin finish!
content.location: Strangleholds Extension

content.description:
The line that everyone who ever climbed

Boy Wonder

looked over at and thought, "Someone should bolt that." Apparently someone did.

Face climbing, a bit of stemming, and steady nerves are needed. The bolting is sparse enough, the angle low enough, and the protuberances numerous enough that falling in certain places would certainly be unpleasant, to say the least.
content.location:
Climbs just left of the large, left-facing corner that greets you when the trail meets

Forgotten Trails

.

content.description:
A strenuous, exciting roof, followed by some uneasy struggling through small holds to briefly easier terrain, followed by a difficult, hard-to-read section just before the chains.

Start up on light-colored slabby terrain for two bolts under the dark-colored, intimidating roof. The third bolt is under the roof and difficult to see from the ground.

Figure out the roof and head onto steep, tan limestone on smallish holds.

A respite follows for a bolt or two, and then a bit of head-scratching confusion follows while fighting the pump before the chains.
content.protection: 8 bolts and chain anchors (shared with the line to the right).
content.location:
After arriving at the east-facing wall at the top of the trail, turn right and walk along the base of the wall. Continue around the point (passing

Long Shadows

on the west side of the blunt arete at the point).

Follow the trail, passing darker-colored, lower-angled rock, then lighter-colored rock containing a broken, angled roof midway up (there are several bolted routes on the lighter-colored rock; the most visible bolt is in a bluish waterstreak).

After a left-facing corner is a tall, narrow wall with a dark-colored roof in the middle. There are two bolted routes on this wall.

Twisted Memories

is the left routes and climbs directly through the roof.

Mind Stream

is the right route; the top anchors are shared by the two lines.

content.description:
This is the .12a first pitch to the other

Trash Kicker

already posted here on MP, the route starts with good pocket climbing, then has some delicate face climbing that is technical in nature, and finishes with a huge mantle to get up to the chains.
content.protection: Quite a few quickdraws and a 60m rope is all you need for the bottom half, the extension requires a 70m.
content.location: This route is just right of the ramp/ dihedral

content.protection: Helmet for your Belayer! 17 bolts to chain anchors. Quickdraws, long draw on the 3rd bolt(placed strangely out of line with the climbing), two 24" slings for the first two bolts above the intermediate anchor. The upper half of the route is currently fixed with decent draws and slings. Chain anchors over the big roof in the angular notch. I know it doesn't seem like its possible looking up, but a 70m rope will safely lower the climber all the way from the anchors!
content.location: This route is the left most climb on Forgotten Trails "Main Wall"- immediately to the right of the obvious ramp/corner feature. The climbing starts from the ramp and continues up the right wall and eventually out the gi-normous tiered roof. The "Main-Wall" is where the approach trail to the crag first deposits you.

content.description: Pockets and edges to a high first bolt, then surmount a small roof and pass the second bolt. Scoot up and under a large roof and clip the third bolt.  Find your way up and around the left side of the big roof, clip the fourth bolt, then figure out a path up and right to the chains.
content.location:
When the trail to

Forgotten Trails

reaches the wall, look left and see the steep trough at the left side of the wall in front of you. To the left of the trough is a small prow; a bolted line appears to the left of the prow. This line is

Boy Wonder

. Go left and find the high first bolt (at about 15 feet or so) of a line that goes up to the left side of the large roof above you. This line is

Tom Slick

.

content.description: A technical and beta-intensive boulder problem constitutes the first 3 bolts. I think it warrants V5. Don't be surprised if at first you feel like there aren't enough holds or feet- its cryptic down low. Above the third bolt you can enjoy mostly sinker pockets and generally good holds- its probably only 11a/b to the chains. This route is an easy tick at the grade- suss out the lower 9 move boulder problem and even someone with poor fitness could hang on to the finish. The climbing is enjoyable, but the rock is less than perfect.
content.protection: All bolts to a chain anchor.
content.location: You will find this route just to the right of Your Onus. It can be easily identified by spoting the "strangle hold" above the second bolt- a right-facing block with lots of brown glue visible on its right side.

content.description:
Same as the main wall routes.

Bouldery start to nice pockets/jugs.
content.location:
Right of

Wasp Stop

, on wall between the main wall and

Long Shadows

.

content.description:
A long and arduous line.

Mind Stream

climbs a straight, yet windy path to an unobvious crux just past its half-way mark. Sustained and pumpy, this route will keep your senses sharp. Take advantage of rest opportunities.
content.protection: Ten quickdraws for a handful of bolts.
content.location:
To locate this route walk around the point and past

Long Shadows

.

Mind Stream

starts just right of a large over-hanging roof. It is almost at the end of the buttress, but just before the third cluster of routes.

content.protection: 10 bolts to a chain anchor. Magnesium carbonate, Spanish sticky rubber, and French belay devices strongly recommended.

content.description: Starts on a fun techy slab. Suggest stick clipping the second. Climbs through not quite vertical sustained section to jug pockets under small roof. This is the crux. Tricky beta leads to a small run out to chains.
content.location: This is the left route on the "3 12's island"

content.description: This is a very unique climb. It climbs to a small roof with pockets then to crimpers and small pockets with good reaches up the arete. It starts overhanging a bit then goes vertical. The view is awesome. Thanks BB and tom caldwell
content.location: As you come to the main wall with around 11 climbs walk down to the right till you come to prominent point. Go around the corner a bit and walk up upwards about 10 feet and that's the belay station.

content.description: The first bolt starts in some broken rock below the terrace, a nicer approach is climbing the quality gray stone and joining in at the second bolt.  From the large stance, the hard climbing begins and is continuous for the next 3 bolts.   Work up a series of underclings and sidepulls to gain the bulge.   Sticking the large flake above the bulge is the crux.   Easier but enjoyable climbing to the end.
content.location: 2nd to right most route on the cliff.   Just to the left of Bumblies in the Dark, share anchors.  Continue past all of the routes and head up a small scree slope.

content.description:
Like nearly all the routes on this wall, the hard-to-read crux is found between the 2nd than 3rd bolt. Good footwork will reduce this "feat" from 12c to 12b.

Perhaps this wall should be referred to as the "hard-start wall?" If you suss the perfect beta, the climb goes from feeling nearly impossible to really only being v4. The remainder of the routes stems and climbs up shattered, but generally solid choss up through sustained pockets and edges- the finish of this route is noticeably more sustained and difficult than the routes to the left. Perhaps 11c/d endurance finish?
content.location: This is the farthest right route on the "Main Wall" - the first wall you encounter when you reach the Forgotten Trails crag. Look for the bolted corner-like feature with shattered tan-colored (golden?) rock.

content.description:
Best of the 3 routes "island of 3 12"

Climbs on sidepulls and some crimps.  Rock is more solid than I thought it would be.

Dream Destroyer

.... Is it because it doesn't look hopeful?

Feet were not invented prior to this route being born. What seems to be the next best option at the wall, turns out to be a footless, footloose, stint up a steep and difficult face. That being said, don't let this stop you, some great holds and good movement make this an exciting, memorable line. Hang on, things will always get better.

Although there is little to work with,

Dream Destroyer

is actually a really nice line, you just need to survive the first 15 feet. Crank on!
content.location:
Dream Destroyer

is the second to last route on the right side of the initial wall. It is the fourth left of

Long Shadows

.

content.description:
Start from the ledge directly below the route and balance your way through blue and tan mineral deposits past three bolts.

Figure out how to get established on and then past the enjoyable, juggy-but-balancy roof. Eyeball the crux, commit, and get past it with a powerful, reachy move.

Cruise to the chains with just a bit of apprehension when jugs turn to slopers near the top.
content.location:
On the west-facing wall. After rounding the point and passing

Long Shadows

you pass a couple of mossy, lower-angled black walls.

After the black walls is a lighter-colored wall with a midpoint roof that descends from upper left to lower right.

Credibility Check

is the right-most route on this wall and turns the roof at the point where it changes from angled to horizontal.

content.description: Slabby start with good crimps, sidepulls and 1 fat under cling. Good holds up to nice rest before crux starts. High left to good pocket starts Crux. Long reach sets up a more sustained crux than the neighbor to the left. This is the worst of the 3 on the "3 12's island."
content.location: The center line on the "3 12's island"

content.description: Really good route on excellent golden stone. I climbed up, clipped the first bolt, got onto the big ledge and clipped the second bolt and then reached down and un-clipped the first bolt to prevent rope drag. Balancy and subtle for the first three bolts. Precise and sequential footwork is necessary. The next three bolts are easier climbing on cool flat and occasionally incut edges. Another crux awaits at the sixth bolt, some flagging might be the trick to grabbing the big left facing flake pinch. Shake out on the giant jug, clip the seventh bolt and eye up the next section. Two crimps and a high foot will get you to the big horn jug and up to the chains.
content.location: This route is the farthest route to the right, or West at the Forgotten Trails. Follow the trail as far as it goes. When the trail disappears, scramble up a small talus slope and look for a boulder leaning against the wall. Go underneath the boulder and over two log landings. Stand on the big pine tree at the base of the route to belay.

content.description: Two lines left left of a BIG corner and around a minor prow. Steep pockets eventually relent to an easy slab. The last few moves are sort-of tough if there isn't any chalk on the holds. Do this part on the left side of the anchor. A little runout at the end.

The climb starts on small side pulls. At the second clip the feet get real tricky. The climb takes you right then left and is fairly technical. The middle section is tenuous - the search for feet continues. Surmount the small bulge with some jugs. At the top it still continues to be hard with crimpers to the chains. The chains are on your right with a large ledge at top. When we were there feet were crumbling off probably making it more challenging. For me it was a sustained and stout 11c wanting to be 11d.
content.location: Third climb from the left. There is a long ramp to your left looking at the wall. See the map on this site.
